monumentInformation.title: Who Built It
details: The Taj Mahal was commissioned by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal, who died during childbirth.
The main architect of the Taj Mahal was Ustad Ahmad Lahori, who led a team of skilled artisans and workers from various regions.

monumentInformation.title: Where It Is Located
details: The Taj Mahal is located in Agra, a historic city in Uttar Pradesh, India, which was a significant city during the Mughal Empire.
The mausoleum stands on the southern bank of the Yamuna River, enhancing its scenic beauty with its reflection in the water.

monumentInformation.title: When It Was Built
details: Construction of the Taj Mahal began in 1632, shortly after the death of Mumtaz Mahal, and involved over 20,000 workers.
The entire structure, including its surrounding complex, was completed in 1653, taking approximately 21 years to finish.

monumentInformation.title: How It Is Protected
details: The Taj Mahal became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983, recognised for its cultural and architectural significance.
It is protected and maintained by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which ensures its preservation and upkeep.

monumentInformation.title: Why It Was Built
details: Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal as a mausoleum for Mumtaz Mahal, symbolising his deep love and grief after her death.
The monument was intended to stand as a symbol of eternal love and to immortalise the grandeur of the Mughal Empire's architectural achievements.
